The mayo in your fridge is actually a physics miracle. Here's why:

Oil and water don't mix. But mayo is 70-80% oil suspended in water.

How? EMULSION.

Egg yolks contain lecithin - a molecule with a water-loving head and oil-loving tail.

During production:
1. Lecithin coats tiny oil droplets
2. These droplets stay suspended in water
3. The result? Stable, creamy mayo

At [COMPANY_NAME], we control droplet size to [MICRON_RANGE] microns.

Too big? Separation.
Too small? Wrong texture.

We monitor this in real-time during every batch.

That's [NUMBER] years of food science in every jar.
